display_asset.caption: Facebook's solar-powered drone, known as Aquila, is said to be ready for in-flight tests.

summaries.body: Facebook said its unmanned drone, intended to bring Internet access to remote areas, is ready for tests in the upper atmosphere, most likely in the United States.
A California wildfire has consumed 8,300 acres north of the Napa Valley and forced 650 people from their homes. The blaze is one of 14 raging in the drought-stricken state.

posts.footer: Giants co-owner John Mara on Jason Pierre-Paul, the team's best defensive player. He said the Giants have not seen Pierre-Paul since he was hurt in a Fourth of July fireworks accident.

summaries.body: I don’t know how many fingers he has.
The little spacecraft that landed on a comet last November has provided an intriguing wealth of data, including the discovery of complex organic molecules.
Chad said its forces had killed 117 Boko Haram insurgents during a two-week military campaign aimed at clearing islands on Lake Chad used by the militants as hideouts.
NBCUniversal is poised to make a pair of investments in the digital media start-ups BuzzFeed and Vox, seeking to appeal to younger millennial viewers, executives said.
A Sierra Leone man died from Ebola in an area where the virus had been gone for months, leading the authorities to quarantine his home village and nurses who treated him.
The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service said it is investigating the killing of Cecil the lion in Zimbabwe, but it has been unable to contact the American dentist accused of the hunt.
A Los Angeles County judge is hearing arguments on Thursday in a case related to plans by the singer Katy Perry to buy a former convent.
Samsung reported its seventh straight profit decline and will be cutting the price of its Galaxy S6 to attract new buyers.

display_asset.caption: Activists protesting Shell’s Arctic aspirations dangled from the St. Johns Bridge in Portland, Ore., on Wednesday.

summaries.body: An icebreaker leased by Shell moved closer to a Portland bridge where antidrilling activists dangling over the water and in kayaks are trying to stop its journey to the Arctic.

display_asset.caption: Searching the site of a landslide caused by heavy rain in Ha Long, Vietnam, on Tuesday.
display_asset.credit: Vietnam News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

summaries.body: Flooding in Vietnam's north has killed at least 17 people, with the continuing rain prompting concerns of landslides.
Two drone strikes in an eastern province in Afghanistan near the Pakistani border have killed 20 militants affiliated with the Islamic State, an Afghan official said.

display_asset.caption: The artist Ai Weiwei placing flowers in a bicycle basket outside his Beijing studio on Dec. 30, 2013, as a protest against restrictions on his travel.
display_asset.credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times

summaries.body: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei said a visa dispute with Britain may restrict his ability to attend the opening of his installation at the Royal Academy of Arts in September.
Jeremy Clarkson, a popular British TV personality and the former host of BBC’s “Top Gear,” said he would film a new car-themed show for Amazon.
An aurora like those at Earth's poles has been spotted around a brown dwarf, the first time the phenomenon has been seen outside our solar system, scientists said.
An Egyptian court has adjourned the long-running retrial of three journalists from Al Jazeera for the ninth time, according to security officials at the courthouse.
Tests found dangerous levels of viruses and bacteria from sewage in Rio de Janeiro waters where Olympians will compete next year, including off Copacabana Beach, above.
At least 15 people died in a landslide in western Nepal caused by torrential rains, the government said.
A second Tokyo district, Setagaya, said it would issue certificates recognizing same-sex partnerships, following a similar move by the Shibuya district in March.
Valuable Cambodian forests are being cleared at an "unprecedented" rate, often by corporations under the pretense of starting rubber plantations, an advocacy group said.
An investigation into a 2010 shooting death of a young mother in Florida that drew national attention found that there is not enough evidence to justify murder charges.

display_asset.caption: Joe McGinn, a UPS driver, fills up his truck with liquid natural gas in Ontario.
display_asset.credit: J. Emilio Flores for The New York Times

summaries.body: UPS said it would buy as much as 46 million gallons of renewable diesel over the next three years as it seeks to displace petroleum-based fuels in its ground fleet.
A court issued a temporary restraining order preventing an anti-abortion group from releasing any video of leaders of a California company that provides fetal tissue for research.
Swedish authorities said a vessel found off Sweden's coast last week was a Russian submarine that likely sank after colliding with a Swedish vessel in 1916.
Three former fraternity members at the University of Virginia sued Rolling Stone for defamation over its now-retracted article about a brutal gang rape.
A gun store in Florida that declared itself a "Muslim-free zone" was sued Wednesday by the state chapter of the Council on American-Islamic Relations.

display_asset.caption: Michel Platini is the president of European soccer’s governing body and a FIFA vice president.

summaries.body: Michel Platini, the president of European soccer’s governing body, said he would run for FIFA president, becoming the most high-profile candidate yet.
A man who jumped a fence to pet cougars at a zoo in Columbus and posted video of it online said he called "Here, kitty" and moved closer when they seemed to respond.

display_asset.caption: Residents of Maldahiyya basti, a colony of families in Varanasi, India, last year.
display_asset.credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times

summaries.body: The United Nations said that India’s population would probably surpass China’s by 2022, not 2028, as the organization had forecast just two years ago.
A wildfire east of California's Napa Valley has charred more than 11 square miles, forcing the evacuation of more than 200 people.
Officials are investigating whether debris that washed up on the Indian Ocean island of La Reunion was from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which went missing in 2014.
The University of Cincinnati said it is closing its main campus in anticipation of grand jury action in the case of the fatal shooting of a motorist pulled over by an officer.

display_asset.caption: The line outside a job fair in Midtown Manhattan in early 2009.
display_asset.credit: Casey Kelbaugh for The New York Times

summaries.body: Chairwoman Janet L. Yellen will speak Wednesday afternoon about when the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates. It's been almost 10 years. Here's how it will work.
Secretary of State John Kerry, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter and other officials are defending the Iran nuclear agreement before a Senate committee.
France is sending 120 additional police officers to Calais after migrants tried to enter the Channel Tunnel to reach Britain. Above, migrants leave a hiding spot near the tunnel.

posts.footer: Tom Brady was commenting on the N.F.L. decision and its finding that he destroyed potential evidence about his role in the deflation of game balls, via Facebook

summaries.body: I am very disappointed by the N.F.L.’s decision to uphold the 4 game suspension against me. I did nothing wrong, and no one in the Patriots organization did either.
Two Zimbabwean men who were paid $50,000 by an American hunter who killed Cecil, the country's best-known lion, arrived in court to face charges of poaching.
Iraq has declared a four-day holiday starting on Thursday as temperatures are set to rise above 123 degrees.

posts.footer: A Times reporter in Greece, via Twitter

summaries.body: Greek PM @tsipras_eu speaks to @stokokkino1055 radio about talks with creditors, the referendum & country's political and economic dilemmas.
A Sudanese migrant died trying to cross to Britain from France early on Wednesday, the French police said, adding to a number of recent deaths in the Channel Tunnel.
France's foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, above, arrived in the Iranian capital of Tehran for the first visit by a top French diplomat in over a decade.
The Los Angeles City Council voted to ban firearm magazines that can hold more than 10 rounds.
An Albuquerque firefighter resigned after hanging up on a 911 caller who was trying to keep a gunshot victim alive.

display_asset.caption: Samuel Pisar in 2009. He wrote new words for Leonard Bernstein’s “Kaddish” Symphony.
display_asset.credit: Ed Alcock for The New York Times

summaries.body: Samuel Pisar, who survived Auschwitz, advised President Kennedy, represented Elizabeth Taylor and created the text for Leonard Bernstein's symphony "Kaddish," died at 86.

posts.footer: Agence France-Presse, via The New Straits Times

summaries.body: Malik Ishaq, the leader of an anti-Shiite militant organization in Pakistan, was killed in a shootout with the police when supporters tried to free him, officials said.

display_asset.caption: Birthday parties have remained free of copyright claims over the song “Happy Birthday to You.” But its use in movies, television and radio has required licensing fees.

summaries.body: Lawyers say they have evidence that the song "Happy Birthday to You" has been in the public domain since 1922, though licensing fees have long been paid for its use.
Hundreds of migrants made their way to the Eurotunnel compound in Calais, France, in a desperate bid to board freight trains bound for Britain.
"The Book of Mormon," the satirical musical about the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, had its Utah debut. All shows in the two-week run are sold out.
The top U.S. military commander urged U.N. member states to increase their commitments to its peacekeeping forces, saying too few are carrying the responsibility.
Gov. Mary Fallin of Oklahoma said she had let her daughter park her trailer on the grounds of the governor's mansion, but she said it would be removed within days.

display_asset.caption: The five-time All-Star Troy Tulowitzki, who had spent his whole career with the Rockies, is now a Blue Jay. Toronto last reached the postseason in 1993.

summaries.body: Troy Tulowitzki, Jose Reyes, Jonathan Papelbon and Ben Zobrist were among the big names on the move in one of the final days before baseball's trading deadline.
Fox News said it was lowering the threshold for participating in its early Republican presidential debate.
The new leader of the Transportation Security Administration said it would retrain thousands of screeners to better detect weapons and other illegal items.
A single mistake by the co-pilot led to the fatal disintegration of a Virgin Galactic space plane during a test flight in October, a safety board concluded.

display_asset.caption: Cecil, a lion who lived in the Hwange National Park in Zimbabwe, in 2012.  He is believed to have been killed by a hunter earlier this month.

summaries.body: A Minnesota dentist has been accused of killing a 13-year-old lion, Cecil, after luring it away from a sanctuary in Zimbabwe. He is being sought on poaching charges.

posts.footer: The Guardian | The New York Times

summaries.body: Miguel Herrera, the coach of Mexico's men's soccer team, was fired after he was accused of punching a reporter. He is known for his boisterous demeanor.

display_asset.caption: Caitlyn and Kylie Jenner in a scene from the show.

summaries.body: The debut of “I Am Cait,” the much-anticipated E! reality series about Caitlyn Jenner, drew solid ratings on Sunday night with 2.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen.
A 15-year-old boy was arrested after police found the body of an 8-year-old girl in a dumpster Monday night. The body is believed to be that of Madyson "Maddy" Middleton.

display_asset.caption: People gathered at a vigil for two teenagers missing since Friday in Jupiter, Fla., on Monday.
display_asset.credit: Thomas Cordy/The Palm Beach Post, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A search for two Florida teenagers who disappeared on a fishing trip entered its fifth day as the Coast Guard expanded its coverage area up the coast to Georgia.

posts.footer: The Times reporter is covering the court appearance of Joyce E. Mitchell, a prison worker, and her plea agreement for helping two convicts escape, via Twitter

summaries.body: Mitchell is standing and speaking to judge. Just got 2 1/3 years for helping #Dannemora #PrisonBreak. Says she understands plea.
The share of Americans who own their homes fell to 63.4 percent in the second quarter, the Census Bureau said. It was lowest reading since 1967.
The United Nations said the civilian death toll from four months of fighting in Yemen has risen to nearly 1,900.
Jon Stewart, the "Daily Show" host, has had two secret meetings with President Obama at the White House that reflect his influence on policy issues.
An inquiry into the death of a former K.G.B. officer who had sought asylum in Britain entered its final, public stages overshadowed by the refusal of a Russian suspect to testify.
The U.S. Navy is investigating a complaint that seeks the evacuation of lawyers from parts of the U.S. base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, following reports of cancer cases.
NATO offered political support for Turkey's campaign against militants in Syria and Iraq at an emergency meeting.
South Korea said it was now virtually free of the Middle East respiratory syndrome that killed 36 people and sickened nearly 200 since an outbreak was declared in May.
The National Transportation Safety Board is to announce on Tuesday the cause of the fatal Virgin Galactic SpaceShipTwo crash in California in October.
Malaysia's prime minister, Najib Razak, who has been embroiled in a financial scandal, fired his deputy, along with the attorney general and other ministers.
Stripe, a San Francisco-based digital payments start-up, announced a partnership with Visa and new funding that values the company at $5 billion.
Jen Welter, who was hired by the Arizona Cardinals for a training camp and preseason coaching position, may be the N.F.L.'s first female coach of any kind.
The State Department upgraded its assessment of Malaysia’s efforts to fight human trafficking. An advocacy group's view of the decision: "Trade trumps human rights.”

posts.footer: Australian Associated Press, via The Guardian

summaries.body: The Australian state of New South Wales said prayer groups in public schools would be audited, following a report that a Sydney student had preached extremism.

display_asset.caption: A scene from the science fiction fantasy “Terminator Genisys.” Experts warned that autonomous weapons could be “feasible within years, not decades.”

summaries.body: Elon Musk, Stephen Hawking and hundreds of experts called for a ban on robots that can kill autonomously, which they said could be "the Kalashnikovs of tomorrow.”

posts.footer: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, referring to Sepp Blatter, the head of FIFA, world soccer's scandal-ridden governing body, via Reuters

summaries.body: I think people like Mr. Blatter or the heads of big international sporting federations, or the Olympic Games, deserve special recognition. If there is anyone who deserves the Nobel Prize, it's those people.

display_asset.caption: Looking for the animal on Sunday in Milwaukee as the citywide search intensified. A grainy cellphone video has given the animal a Bigfoot-like celebrity.
display_asset.credit: Michael Sears/Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, via Associated Press

summaries.body: No one is sure what kind of creature is on the loose in Milwaukee — a lion or cougar, perhaps? — but the search has captivated the city.
An 18-year-old Palestinian man was shot and killed by Israeli forces in the West Bank while trying to evade arrest, the police said.
A pledge by Saudi Arabia to halt its military operations in Yemen failed to stop fighting on Monday as a humanitarian aid group warned of widespread starvation.

display_asset.caption: Junior Seau with his daughter, Sydney, at his induction into the San Diego Chargers' hall of fame in 2011.

summaries.body: The family of Junior Seau reiterated its stance that his daughter, Sydney, should speak live and in her own words at her father’s Pro Football Hall of Fame induction.
The inquiry into the poisoning death in London of a former K.G.B. officer, Alexander V. Litvinenko, was delayed with the failure of a key suspect to testify by video from Moscow.
Phil Ivey, a top professional poker player, is countersuing an Atlantic City casino that accused him of cheating while playing baccarat.
A study of anoles trapped in tree resin found that different species of the lizards have not changed much over millions of years.
U.N. observers in Burundi said the election that won President Pierre Nkurunziza a third term took place in an environment that was not conducive for a credible election.
A judge said BP would begin paying up to $1 billion in settlements to compensate Gulf Coast governments for lost tax revenue and other damages from the 2010 oil spill.
Thailand is among nearly 24 nations making little to no effort to stop human trafficking, while Malaysia improved its effort to combat it, a State Department report said.
Comcast, the country’s largest cable operator, and Discovery said they had reached a multiyear agreement over the fees Comcast pays to carry Discovery networks.
Fires rose south of Beirut because of a dispute over a trash dump as protesters closed a highway to keep the government from moving mounting trash from the capital.

display_asset.caption: Perry Cohen, left, and Austin Stephanos have been missing since Friday.

summaries.body: The Coast Guard is searching for two teenagers who disappeared off the Florida coast while on a fishing trip. The Coast Guard found their capsized boat on Sunday.
French farmers angry over low prices turned back hundreds of trucks at the German border, looking for cargos of foreign meat and milk products.
Chinese authorities plan to start a second cruise ship link to the disputed Paracel Islands in the South China Sea, state news media reported. Vietnam also claims them.
Thailand's beleaguered national airline said it would halt flights to the U.S. as part of efforts to end years of losses.
The inquiry into the poisoning death in London of a former K.G.B. officer was set to find out on Monday whether a prominent Russian suspect had withdrawn from the case.

display_asset.caption: Indian soldiers during an exchange of gunfire with militants holed up in a police station in Gurdaspur on Monday.

summaries.body: Gunmen in Indian Army uniforms opened fire on a civilian bus and then took over a police station in Punjab State, killing at least five people, the police said.

display_asset.caption: Alan Bunce and Peg Lynch in a publicity photo for “Ethel and Albert,” a show she wrote about the mundane details of life.

summaries.body: Peg Lynch, who wrote and starred in one of the first television sitcoms, "Ethel and Albert," died at 98. A pioneering woman in the industry, she wrote nearly 11,000 scripts.
Twenty-one people were killed in a gunfight at a wedding in northern Afghanistan, a provincial governor said.
The last person in South Korea being watched for symptoms of Middle East respiratory syndrome was released from isolation. The country has reported no new cases in weeks.

display_asset.caption: A protester in Puerto Rico whose sign translates as “We didn’t take out a loan. We didn’t see a dime. We’re not going to pay.”

summaries.body: Economists working for hedge funds said collecting unpaid taxes could help solve Puerto Rico's debt crisis. Above, a protester's sign reads in part, "We're not going to pay."
Adam Brookman, a nurse who said he was forced to work with ISIS in Syria, appeared in an Australian court charged with providing support to a terrorist organization.

posts.footer: New York Magazine, whose new cover features dozens of women who have accused the comedian of sexual assault, via Twitter

summaries.body: 35 women speak about being assaulted by Bill Cosby, and the culture that wouldn't listen: http://t.co/H5dss5F2F4 http://t.co/RCF0BWBrxA
